content.text:
# Draft:Woodson County Historical Museum

The Woodson County Historical Museum is a small museum in Yates Center, Kansas. It is run by the Woodson County Historical Society and shares the history of the people, towns, and traditions of Woodson County, Kansas.
Location and Building
The museum is located at 208 West Mary Street in Yates Center. The building is part of the county’s history;it was first built in 1878 as a church. Over the years, it was used for other things, including a chicken hatchery, before becoming a museum. On the museum grounds, there are also several old buildings that were moved there, such as a one-room schoolhouse, a small church, and a log cabin from the Daniel family farm near Big Sandy Creek.
History
The Woodson County Historical Society started in 1965, and the museum opened a few years later. In 1982, the museum was broken into and several items were stolen, including antiques and tools. Many of them were recovered with help from law enforcement.
Collections and Exhibits
The museum shows what life was like for early settlers in Woodson County. Some of the main exhibits include:
* A real pioneer log cabin from the Daniel family
* Displays about early settlers and how Yates Center became the county seat
* Civil War and Native American artifacts
* Old farming tools, machines, and photos
* A “farm room” that shows the building’s time as a hatchery
Importance
The Woodson County Historical Museum helps keep local history alive. It teaches visitors about the people and events that shaped the county and helps support tourism in Southeast Kansas.
Visiting
The museum is located at 208 W. Mary Street in Yates Center, Kansas. It is usually open during certain seasons, and visitors can contact the museum to schedule tours or learn about special events.
